cleaned_text: balance Energy is needed not only when a person is physically active but even when the body is lying motionless. Depending on an individual's level of physical activity, between 50 and 80 percent of the [energy](https://www.britannica.com/science/energy) expended each day is devoted to basic metabolic processes (basal [metabolism](https://www.britannica.com/science/metabolism)), which enable the body to stay warm, breathe, pump blood, and conduct numerous physiological and biosynthetic activities, including synthesis of new tissue in growing children and in pregnant and lactating women. Digestion and subsequent processing of [food](https://www.britannica.com/topic/food) by the body also uses energy and produces heat. This phenomenon, known as the thermic effect of food (or diet-induced thermogenesis), accounts for about 10 percent of daily energy expenditure, varying somewhat with the [composition](https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/composition) of the diet and prior dietary practices. Adaptive thermogenesis, another small but important component of energy expenditure, reflects alterations in metabolism due to changes in ambient temperature, [hormone](https://www.britannica.com/science/hormone) production, emotional stress, or other factors. Finally, the most [variable](https://www.britannica.com/topic/variable-mathematics-and-logic) component in energy expenditure is [physical activity](https://www.britannica.com/topic/physical-activity), which includes [exercise](https://www.britannica.com/topic/exercise-physical-fitness) and other voluntary activities as well as involuntary activities such as fidgeting, shivering, and maintaining posture. Physical activity accounts for 20 to 40 percent of the total energy expenditure, even less in a very sedentary person and more in someone who is extremely active. Basal or resting energy [expenditure](https://www.britannica.com/dictionary/expenditure) is correlated primarily with lean body mass (fat-free mass and essential fat, excluding storage fat), which is the metabolically active tissue in the body. At rest, organs such as the liver, brain, heart, and kidney have the highest metabolic activity and, therefore, the highest need for energy, while muscle and bone require less energy, and body fat even less. Besides body composition, other factors affecting basal metabolism include age, sex, body temperature, and thyroid hormone levels. The [basal metabolic rate](https://www.britannica.com/science/basal-metabolic-rate) (BMR), a precisely defined measure of the energy expenditure necessary to support life, is determined under controlled and standardized conditions—shortly after awakening in the morning, at least 12 hours after the last meal, and with a comfortable room temperature. Because of practical [considerations](https://www.britannica.com/dictionary/considerations), the BMR is rarely measured; the resting energy expenditure (REE) is determined under less stringent conditions, with the individual resting comfortably about 2 to 4 hours after a meal. In practice, the BMR and REE differ by no more than 10 percent—the REE is usually slightly higher—and the terms are used interchangeably. Energy expenditure can be assessed by direct calorimetry, or measurement of heat dissipated from the body, which employs apparatuses such as water-cooled garments or insulated chambers large enough to accommodate a person. However, energy expenditure is usually measured by the less cumbersome techniques of indirect calorimetry, in which heat produced by the body is calculated from measurements of [oxygen](https://www.britannica.com/science/oxygen) inhaled, [carbon dioxide](https://www.britannica.com/science/carbon-dioxide) exhaled, and urinary [nitrogen](https://www.britannica.com/science/nitrogen) excreted. The BMR (in kilocalories per day) can be roughly estimated using the following formula: BMR = 70 × (body weight in kilograms)3/4. The energy costs of various activities have been measured (see table). While resting may require as little as 1 kilocalorie per minute, [strenuous](https://www.britannica.com/dictionary/strenuous) work may demand 10 times that much. Mental activity, though it may seem taxing, has no appreciable effect on energy requirement. A 70-kg (154-pound) [man](https://www.britannica.com/topic/human-being), whose REE over the course of a day might be 1,750 kilocalories, could expend a total of 2,400 kilocalories on a very sedentary day and up to 4,000 kilocalories on a very active day. Excess food energy is stored in small amounts as [glycogen](https://www.britannica.com/science/glycogen), a short-term storage form of [carbohydrate](https://www.britannica.com/science/carbohydrate) in muscle and liver, and as fat, the body's main energy reserve found in adipose tissue. [Adipose tissue](https://www.britannica.com/science/adipose-tissue) is mostly fat (about 87 percent), but it also contains some [protein](https://www.britannica.com/science/protein) and [water](https://www.britannica.com/science/water). In order to lose 454 grams (one pound) of adipose tissue, an energy [deficit](https://www.britannica.com/dictionary/deficit) of about 3,500 kilocalories (14.6 megajoules) is required. Body mass, body [fat](https://www.britannica.com/topic/fat), and body water The [human body](https://www.britannica.com/science/human-body) consists of materials similar to those found in foods; however, the relative proportions differ, according to genetic dictates as well as to the unique life experience of the individual. The body of a healthy lean man is composed of roughly 62 percent water, 16 percent fat, 16 percent protein, 6 percent minerals, and less than 1 percent carbohydrate, along with very small amounts of vitamins and other miscellaneous substances. Females usually carry more fat (about 22 percent in a healthy lean woman) and slightly less of the other components than do males of comparable weight. The body's different compartments—lean body mass, body fat, and body water—are constantly adjusting to changes in the internal and external [environment](https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/environment) so that a state of [dynamic](https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/dynamic) [equilibrium](https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/equilibrium) ( [homeostasis](https://www.britannica.com/science/homeostasis)) is maintained. Tissues in the body are continuously being broken down ( [catabolism](https://www.britannica.com/science/catabolism)) and built up ( [anabolism](https://www.britannica.com/science/anabolism)) at varying rates. For example, the [epithelial](https://www.britannica.com/science/epithelium) cells lining the [digestive tract](https://www.britannica.com/science/gastrointestinal-tract) are replaced at a dizzying speed of every three or four days, while the life span of red blood cells is 120 days, and [connective tissue](https://www.britannica.com/science/connective-tissue) is renewed over the course of several years. Although estimates of the percentage of body fat can be made by direct inspection, this approach is imprecise. Body fat can be measured indirectly using fairly precise but costly methods, such as underwater weighing, total body [potassium](https://www.britannica.com/science/potassium) counting, and dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DXA). However, more practical, [albeit](https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/albeit) less accurate, methods are often used, such as [anthropometry](https://www.britannica.com/science/anthropometry), in which subcutaneous fat at various sites is measured using skinfold calipers; bioelectrical impedance, in which resistance to a low-intensity electrical current is used to estimate body fat; and near infrared interactance, in which an infrared light aimed at the biceps is used to assess fat and protein interaction. Direct measurement of the body's various compartments can only be performed on cadavers. The composition of the body tends to change in somewhat predictable ways over the course of a lifetime—during the growing years, in pregnancy and lactation, and as one ages—with corresponding changes in [nutrient](https://www.britannica.com/science/nutrient) needs during different phases of the life cycle (see the section [Nutrition throughout the life cycle](https://www.britannica.com/science/human-nutrition/Nutrition-throughout-the-life-cycle#ref250663)). Regular physical exercise can help [attenuate](https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/attenuate) the age-related loss of lean tissue and increase in body fat.
